segments.text: This is where Ben started taping the planes coming in and then you and he went out and played and I think there's some talking in there by Reverend Robert Shuler, but you'll just keep on playing until you get through to where your grandmother and I started talking. Okay?
I just want to add a few words as to what the snowstorm was like here.
And when you were on your way home Sunday,
we were getting reports that the storm was coming into Calgary
and we wondered if you were going to run into it.
At any rate, we had about four to five inches of snow here
and it looked as though it would never go away.
There's that much of it laying around.
And then yesterday afternoon it started thawing
and now this afternoon the lawns are all bare
and the only snow that's around is on the north side of the buildings
where the sun don't get at it.
So we're back into some reasonable weather.
I might add that Wally and Willa came up on Wednesday night.
She was coming up for a doctor's appointment
and Willa had an appointment also for some tests.
And they stayed Wednesday night and then Thursday they had their appointments
and they went up and had supper at Joni's
and then they came back here
and naturally each night we played rummy until about one o'clock
and there weren't any great winners or losers in the game.
And they left this morning about 11 o'clock
and they planned to go to Arizona the first part of next week.
So that's all the last we'll see of them for six months
unless something happens if they decide to come home.
And anyway, I don't know what else there is to tell you
and don't remember God loves you and so do I.
Don't forget, I mean, that God loves you and so do I.
And then, run around the kitchen two times and say hi-ya grams every time you go around, okay?
Do the jumping jacks, um, right at the door of the kitchen.
Leslie, your grandmother and I are now going to try to answer the questions
that you asked regarding the Depression in 1930.
And you will find some discrepancies in our taping
because we're not experts at it like you and Ben.
But from now on, I'll have Grandma read out your question
How did you make coffee in those days?
Well, some of the farmers roasted wheat or roasted barley
and boiled it and used it for coffee.
And I can tell you it was plenty hard to take.
But I imagine you did have coffee if you wanted to buy it.
Oh, yes, you could buy coffee and it was cheap.
But then who had the money to buy it?
Did your family have a Bennett buggy?
No, we never had a Bennett buggy in our family somehow or other.
How much was milk and bread?
Well, you could buy bread in the stores at 10 cents a loaf
and milk at about 5 cents a quart.
In fact, you could get cream, good thick cream for 10 cents a quart.
And it wasn't pasteurized, was it?
Straight from the cows, so to speak.
How much were wages in those days if you had a job?
Well, many young men had to work on the farms for $5 a month.
Most of their wages were about 40 cents an hour.
That would be like $3 a day.
If you were working in a plant or in a coal mine,
In the stores, if you were a clerk in the store,
Well, I had a business and I used to take $8 a week out.
But I lived at home, so I didn't have to pay much board and room.
But that was enough to buy clothes on.
We never had a Bennett buggy.
We had a car, but we couldn't afford to buy a license for it.
I don't remember making a coffee or anything like that.
But I know things were pretty tough.
But everybody else was poorer, so it didn't seem to hurt too much.
Yeah, everybody was on the same level.
You'd be called to a dance for $0.35 and they'd throw in a lunch.
The church had a lot of card parties and they'd serve a lunch after.
And bingo parties for a nickel a game or whatever.
But anyway, we had a good time, even if we didn't have any money.
Maybe we had a better time than the teenagers do nowadays.
And if you had a jigsaw puzzle, when you were through with it, you didn't throw it away.
You'd give it to a neighbor and they'd give it to another neighbor.
We used to do a lot of skating and we lived around a country where it was hilly,
so we did a lot of tobogganing and skiing.
We didn't have the warmest clothes in the world.
But we always seemed to manage.
The clothes we had in those days compared to today were really inadequate.
No such a thing as a parka or a hood.
To high school, wearing long underwear.
Now, I can just see the young girls wearing long underwear to high school now.
It was the same as long johns.
I said you had to walk about a slow mile to get there.
Well, anyway, Les, this is about it.
And I hope this did you some good for your school work.
Well, during the depression years, I spent a lot of time on the farm.
And wages were not of consideration.
But one winter, I did work for my brother.
And I got $8 a month, and I worked from 6 o'clock in the morning until 6 o'clock at night
every day, seven days a week.
a week. We had sixty head of cattle, fifty sheep, about forty horses, and maybe sixty
or seventy pigs, and a hundred hens that were laying eggs. And by the time you got up in
the morning and made the rounds and gave them all their breakfast, and then you come in
to the house, I can tell you you were ready to eat your breakfast too, and you didn't
question what it was, you ate whatever was prepared for you. But all in all, we had a
lot of fun there. We used to get together with the neighbors and play cards, and we
played poker, and we used matches for money. No money ever exchanged hands, it was just
everybody was allotted a hundred matches, and then from that you'd see who was the best
card player at the end of the night. You'd put the matches back in the box when you were
We'd get together as families, total families, you know, from sixty years down to six years
old, and you'd play games, all kinds of crazy games that everyone was involved in. And you
had more laughs than a little bit, and you went home feeling happy. You never spent any
money, you didn't have any money to spend. If you went to a dance, I said earlier, it
would cost you a country dance, it would cost you maybe thirty-five cents admission, and
along with that there was a lunch for us, because everything was so cheap to make sandwiches
for next to nothing. Oh, it was a great life, and we were all... I was young at that time,
and everybody else was young, and we were accepted, the fact that we were all on the
same level, lived life one day at a time. So now, we'll put this in, and I want to say,
I just put this on the end of the tape that you and Ben had been playing with, and I don't
know what's on the start of the tape, or how far, but you'll start the tape. You'll go
right to the start of the tape, and then you'll go until you come to our story. Right now
I'll turn the tape back to zero. Goodbye for now.
then the next election that you're gonna hear is you can record over the last one
you heard or or the one you hear this just listen to it carefully and there's
some boring parts but just be patient and it's gonna be something like five
minutes long okay and listen there might there's gonna be a pause at the end and
just listen to it for the little pause and then listen to the next part bye
Okay, I'm recording over something, so I just want to tell everyone that, um, I'm having
fun at Regina, and Ben, you know that note I wrote you at home saying I want to be your
friend and everything, well, I'm going to say it here now, and I'm going to keep doing
it until you do be my friend, okay, this is what I'm going to say, Ben, I want you
to be my friend, and I want you to be my pen pal, and we keep writing each other, you know
what a pen pal is, when you're in Toronto, and I don't want, I don't want, I want you
to write me, and I don't care how you do it, just write me, okay?
Thank you, I love you, Ben.
Mrs. Jekyll, how do you think about this stuff about raising cat food?
I hate it! That's why I just dumped my cat, because there's no other food that I can give my cat.
Well, Mrs. Jekyll, how do you think about this?
I guess what? I hate your cousin, I hate this place, and I think that...
Thank you, Mrs. Jekyll, that was a very touching speech.
Want me to do it again?
That was a very other touching speech, and different words, too.
Because we have to entertain the Couch Patch Kids.
Okay, Couch Patch Kids, come in.
We just closed the door for you.
My name is Selena, and his name is Obi.
Yeah? Who's that little friend you brought with you?
Oh, that's Bluey, with her little kids, Greeny and Pinky.
No, you're not. You're one year old.
Did any of your kids do anything wrong?
Greeny went away because he was looking for his father, Purpley, once.
And we found her, and I gave her a big smack.
She's grounded from her TV set down in my clothes for a long time, but Pinky can watch it in the next room.
How long has Greeny been grounded?
Greeny, has anything bad happened to you?
My mommy doesn't love me anymore, because Obi came.
I got real cold once, and I sneezed.
And I blew myself clear across the room.
And I still got the lump on my head.
Now you don't have it anymore.
You just have a sucked-in head.
How many dimples do you have?
How many do you have, Sweeney?
We're going to have to let you go, and we're going to interview me.

I'm nine years old, I'm ten years old, and my mom's thirty-six, Ben's thirteen turning fourteen, I'm ten turning eleven, Blaze is thirty-eight turning thirty-nine, my mom's thirty-six, my Auntie Jane just had a new baby, she already has two, and it's a boy, and I'm going down to P.E.L.

When I go to my dad's in twelve days, we're going to have a whole bunch of fun, and we're going to go to P.E.L. and we're going to have a whole bunch of fun there, and we just hope that my dad's back to some breakout again.
So, Leslie, I guess we're going to have to go unless we have someone else come in here to interview.
How many do you have now?
Can you bring your kids here?
Wait, do you have Noisy feet, too?
Just say them when I point to you.
I guess we're going to have to go now.
Be with you and just don't yell.
Hello, we are going through the ground again.
So then, I hope you listen to that very carefully, because it's all the truth.
And that Mrs. Hyde, like you know at the beginning it said, is supposed to be Mrs. Jekyll.
Well, there were two Mrs. Jekylls, but the last Mrs. Jekyll was supposed to be a Mrs. Hyde.
So, um, what it meant when it said they were raising cat food prices, they were going, cat food, raising cat food, it meant they were raising cat food prices.
And those ants going like this, I was supposed to be going like this, because they were coming in troops.
Here's a real ant, here's a real ant on this horse.
Okay, okay, can you hear the vacuum?
Okay, here's an ant on this horse.
Here's an ant on this horse.
Hello, everybody. This is T'Leslie. You have to try to find me, okay?
You'll never do it, though. I know you're in here right now, but you don't know what I'm saying, because, okay.
So, I'll play this one. I want you to come and find me, and I'll turn it up kind of loud.
Now, let's hit this. Okay. Okay, so try to find me, and don't do anything bad, you know.
And don't take the tape recorder around, because Grandpa will get really mad, okay?
Too bad you suck, I hate your car!
I heard clicks and then I looked and then I saw your head.
Liar, because I clicked it out there.
Lesslie said the oomph mark was a two, it was real.
Oh, sometimes I can change it.
What's up, what's up, what's up?
That's from when I was sitting on it, though.
Can we sit there on towels?
Okay, if we get dry towels?
Right now, I'm giving my interview.
What's the easy trick? What's the easy trick? What's the easy trick? What's the easy trick?
Leslie's singing now because she's so stupid. Listen to this. You gotta hear this. It's so funny. It's so funny. So funny.
I don't know if she's singing anymore or what.
I went to the washroom and I walked in.
I walked in and I didn't know he was there.
So, Leslie's a pervert. You can tell by what she just said, eh? She walked in going .
Leslie's a jerk. Leslie's a jerk.
She just tried to pull up her pants like a little perv here.
That was her perfect singing there, just the
Now she's stomping out of the room like a little cry, baby
We're gonna walk over there and bugger some more
Can you hear the typical run?
I see her in the closet. What do you have to say about me finding you in this closet in the back hall by the dryer? Here's the dryer.
Okay, now what do you have to say about me finding you, Leslie?
Unless I can beat the reporter.
I have an idea. I'll just turn off the typical and ask Leslie.
Leslie just said no to that idea. Yeah?
Do you have some of this?
Well, it turns out it's kind of hot.
It's not hot. Do you like a peanut butter sandwich?
I'm going to have a peanut butter sandwich.
I'm going to have a peanut butter sandwich.
I'm going to have a peanut butter sandwich.
You said bad things about me, so I can say bad things about you.
Well, you have to because I'm recording.
I don't have to say anything about you.
Okay, I'll plug in the other one again.
No, I'm not going to let you look anymore.
It doesn't matter what the mic turned on and off, so your plan didn't work!
Oh, it looks like part of one of those coffee tables from those classical tables.
You know, the bottom underneath the holes...
What was it in, your food?
I laid it on the floor, I found it on the floor.
I know, but is that what it's from?
Don't put it in the toilet!
No plastic glass in the toilet.
Yeah, he would have done that too.
He used to put it on the floor or something.
Threw it and tried to throw it in the garbage and missed it.
And he could have just done it there.
He's one of the grandchildren, that's for sure.
You could place in your picture on there, right?
Keep you placing it over there?
You don't get one to place over there.
Surprise, what's on my face there?
Were your friends sorry to see you go?
Well, my friends were, but not the regular people in my class.
Everybody was clapping when they found out I was leaving.
In my class, everybody was clapping except for Gladys.
In the student of the month, the second last day of school,
Mr. Spavor made all the people who were going to the new school stand up.
And, um, we all stood up.
Some of those student of the month's classes left.
So we in fact, we thought,
Oh, gee, we're going to get some classes.
And then they found out they're for the teachers.
Is that a Catholic school that you're going to?
It almost makes you wonder what it's all about when you've got a thing like this and you try and use it.
And when you come back to turn it on, play it for an hour and you get nothing out of it.
You never break things by using them, you break them by playing with them.
That's been my experience at any rate.
Now you wonder what the kids are doing.
Used to be in with some San Francisco band, but now mostly just feel that thing.
Do you have any comment Ben?
